pullRequest.title: Fix for Issue #10670: Allow JAX-RS Application.getSingletons() to handle CDI proxy classes

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,205 @@
+/*******************************************************************************
+ * Copyright (c) 2020 IBM Corporation and others.
+ * All rights reserved. This program and the accompanying materials
+ * are made available under the terms of the Eclipse Public License v1.0
+ * which accompanies this distribution, and is available at
+ * http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl-v10.html
+ *
+ * Contributors:
+ *     IBM Corporation - initial API and implementation
+ *******************************************************************************/
+package com.ibm.ws.jaxrs20.cdi12.fat.test;
+
+import static org.junit.Assert.assertTrue;

nodes.bodyText: These should be put in the @Before (to start the server) and @After (to stop it) methods - both methods might need to throw Exception.  Once in those methods, it will apply to all tests, so you can remove these lines from each test method.

Just a thought, but maybe this method could be put in some utils class so that we only need it in one place - then all of the getSingletons() methods that need to invoke it could just call CDIUtils.getBean(<resourceClass>);. What do you think?

Just a thought here... I think it is also possible for CDI to inject the ServletContext (using @Inject ServletContext servletContext2; - maybe we could include this in the test too?  That would ensure that ServletContext injection works regardless of who injects it.
It might be good to test ServletContext injection in the resource classes too.
nodes.diffHunk:

+package com.ibm.ws.jaxrs20.cdi12.fat.contextandCDI;
+
+
+import javax.ws.rs.GET;
+import javax.ws.rs.Path;
+import javax.ws.rs.core.Response;
+
+import javax.enterprise.context.ApplicationScoped;
+
+@ApplicationScoped
+@Path("resource")
+public class TestResource {
+

nodes.bodyText: It seems weird to be importing an "internal" package.  Please make sure that the CDI team is ok with us using this class - possibly a better approach would be to put CDI Utils in a different (more public) package.
